title: In a Post-Roe World, the Future of Digital Privacy Looks Even Grimmer
abstract: The sheer amount of tech tools and knowledge required to discreetly seek an abortion underlines how wide open we are to surveillance.
byline: By Natasha Singer and Brian X. Chen

title: For Blind Internet Users, the Fix Can Be Worse Than the Flaws
abstract: Companies say their A.I.-powered tools are the best way to fix accessibility problems online, but many blind people find they make websites harder to use.

multimedia.caption: Patrick Perdue used to shop online for radio equipment before his preferred website’s new accessibility software made it harder — not easier — to navigate, he said.
multimedia.copyright: Don Brodie for The New York Times

title: Twitter Sues Musk After He Tries Backing Out of $44 Billion Deal
abstract: The question of whether Elon Musk must buy Twitter, as he agreed to do in April, is headed to a court in Delaware.
byline: By Kate Conger and Lauren Hirsch

multimedia.caption: Twitter sued Elon Musk. He had agreed to buy the company for $44 billion but now wants to terminate the deal.

title: The Tech Magic That Unleashed Your Best
abstract: Our readers tell us about the surprising ways in which tech has helped them discover new worlds.

title: Stripe, the payments start-up, lowers internal valuation 28 percent.
abstract: A sell-off of tech stocks in the public markets has prompted private start-ups to evaluate whether their soaring valuations over the past two years will hold up.

title: Twitter suffers a global outage at a delicate moment for the company.
abstract: The social networking site went offline on Thursday morning, affecting users worldwide. The interruption comes as the company is fighting Elon Musk over a proposed acquisition.

abstract: A scarcity of semiconductors and raw materials held back production, but buyers remain enthusiastic.

title: Apple Ends Consulting Agreement With Jony Ive, Its Former Design Leader
abstract: Three years after promising to work “long into the future” with the man behind its candy-colored computers, Apple and Mr. Ive are through.

title: How Deep Is Our Love for Prime Day?
abstract: Probably not very, judging by our past flings with online fads.

title: How Elon Musk Damaged Twitter and Left It Worse Off
abstract: Mr. Musk swooped in and exposed Twitter’s lack of business and financial prospects. After criticizing the company’s weaknesses, he now wants to back out of buying it.
byline: By Kate Conger and Mike Isaac

title: Restaurants Face an Extortion Threat: A Bad Rating on Google
abstract: Emails sent to dozens of restaurants, including those with Michelin stars, threaten a barrage of one-star reviews unless owners pay.

title: What Is Delaware’s Court of Chancery and Its Role in Elon Musk’s Twitter Deal?
abstract: Twitter has sued Mr. Musk to force a sale of the company, and the case will be determined by a 230-year-old court in Delaware.

title: Twitter’s stock falls further as doubts swirl over Elon Musk’s takeover.
abstract: Shares have lost a third of their value since April 25, when the company’s board accepted Mr. Musk’s offer.

title: What’s Next in the Elon Musk-Twitter Saga? A Court Battle
abstract: Most legal experts say Twitter has the upper hand. But Musk revels in brinkmanship.
byline: By Lauren Hirsch and Kate Conger

title: What Are Spam Bots and Why They’re an Issue in Elon Musk’s Twitter Deal
abstract: Bots can tweet at people, share tweets, follow and be followed by other people. And there are good bots and bad.

title: Elon Musk Moves to End $44 Billion Deal to Buy Twitter
abstract: In a regulatory filing on Friday, Mr. Musk said Twitter was in “material breach” of the acquisition agreement.
byline: By Kate Conger and Lauren Hirsch

title: Even in Death, Internet Explorer Lives On in South Korea
abstract: Why a country known for blazing broadband and innovative devices remains tethered to a browser that most of the world abandoned long ago.
byline: By Daisuke Wakabayashi and Jin Yu Young

multimedia.caption: A tombstone in South Korea marks the final days of Internet Explorer. Microsoft shut down the web browser in June, but it is still needed for a small number of critical banking and government-related tasks in South Korea.
